Wheat.Land Preparation: Plough, level, and harrow the land, ensuring thorough soil preparation. Break soil clods and incorporate organic matter for improved fertility.

Wheat.Seeding and Irrigation: Sow wheat seeds at recommended depth and spacing. Provide sufficient irrigation during tillering and flowering stages for optimal growth.

Wheat.Fertilization: Apply nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium fertilizers based on soil nutrient levels. Split nitrogen application to promote even crop development.

Wheat.Pest and Disease Management: Monitor for pests like aphids and diseases such as rust. Use recommended pesticides and fungicides as needed.

Rice.Land Preparation: Level the field and create puddles to suppress weed growth. Manage water levels effectively for flooded conditions.

Rice.Seeding and Transplanting: Direct seed or transplant rice seedlings according to cultivation method. Maintain proper water depth throughout various growth stages.

Rice.Fertilization: Apply nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium fertilizers based on soil test results. Adjust fertilizer application to meet the crop's nutrient requirements.

Rice.Weed Control: Implement herbicides or manual weeding strategies for effective weed control. Adopt integrated weed management practices.

Maize (Corn).Land Preparation: Plough and harrow the field to create a fine seedbed. Ensure adequate drainage to prevent waterlogging.

Maize (Corn).Seeding and Crop Rotation: Plant maize seeds at recommended depth and spacing. Rotate maize with other crops to manage pests and diseases effectively.

Maize (Corn).Fertilization: Apply nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium fertilizers based on soil nutrient levels. Consider side-dressing nitrogen during the growing season.

Maize (Corn).Harvesting: Harvest maize when kernels are fully developed, and moisture content is optimal. Use recommended harvesting equipment for maximum yield.

Soybeans.Land Preparation: Prepare a well-drained seedbed and ensure proper soil fertility. Consider inoculating seeds with rhizobia for nitrogen fixation.

Soybeans.Seeding and Growth Stages: Plant soybean seeds at the recommended depth. Pay attention to growth stages for timely management practices such as pest control and irrigation.

Soybeans.Fertilization: Apply balanced fertilizers, paying attention to the crop's nitrogen needs. Consider foliar feeding during critical growth stages.

Soybeans.Harvesting: Harvest soybeans when pods are fully developed, and seeds are mature. Use appropriate harvesting equipment to minimize losses.

Potatoes.Land Preparation: Loosen soil to a good depth and remove stones. Incorporate well-rotted organic matter for improved soil structure and water retention.

Potatoes.Planting and Hilling: Plant potato tubers in furrows or beds and hill soil around plants during the growing season. This encourages tuber development and prevents greening.

Potatoes.Fertilization: Apply a balanced fertilizer with a higher potassium content for improved tuber quality. Monitor soil nutrient levels and adjust fertilizer application accordingly.

Potatoes.Harvesting: Harvest potatoes when the tops have died back, and the skins are set. Carefully dig up tubers to avoid damage during harvesting.

Cotton.Land Preparation: Prepare a well-drained seedbed, and ensure soil is free of debris and clods. Incorporate organic matter for moisture retention and nutrient availability.

Cotton.Planting and Growth: Plant cotton seeds at recommended spacing and depth. Monitor plant growth for timely irrigation and pest control, especially during flowering.

Cotton.Fertilization: Apply nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium fertilizers based on soil test results. Supplement with micronutrients as needed for optimal cotton fiber development.

Cotton.Harvesting: Harvest cotton when bolls have matured, and fibers are fully developed. Use mechanical harvesters for efficiency and to minimize fiber damage.
